Reference: Revision of ISO standards for bromate analysis
English title: - Revision ISO 15061:2001, Water quality — Determination of dissolved bromate — Method by liquid chromatography of ions - Revision ISO 11206:2011, Water quality — Determination of dissolved bromate — Method using ion chromatography (IC) and post column reaction (PCR)
Note: Bromate is characterized by high environmental persistence and presents various toxic effects on aquatic ecosystems and human health. Owing to the increasing implementation of ozonation processes at wastewater treatment plants and the associated risk of bromate formation, a legally defensible determination of bromate in wastewater is essential. Consequently, the ISO standards 15061 and 11206 should be revised with regard to their scope, sample pretreatment, and potential interferences. Ballots are launched among SC 2 members via the CIB-Portal in order to receive their vote on Draft ISO/TC 147/SC 2 Resolution C008/2025 “Revision of ISO 15061:2001” ISO/TC 147/SC 2 decides to revise ISO 15061:2001, Water quality — Determination of dissolved bromate — Method by liquid chromatography of ions” Development track 24 months Project leader: Carlotta Wilke (C.Wilke@isa.rwth-aachen.de) WG in charge: WG 33 “Ion chromatography methods”  The current scope is expanded to treated waste water The project is starting at stage (40.00) Project plan (target dates): Submission of DIS (40.00): 2027-01-30Submission of FDIS (50.00) (if any): 2027-10-30Publication: 2028-03-01Using the Online Development platform: OSD option: YES OSD starting material: existing MS word file The revision of ISO 15061:2001 supports the UN Sustainable Development Goal 6 (Clean water and sanitation) , as the project addresses the safeguarding of water quality in the context of modern wastewater treatment, by enabling the legally defensible detection of a toxicologically relevant by-product of ozonation. In doing so, it supports evidence-based regulation, the protection of human health and ecosystems, and sustainable, safe water management. Resolution 165/2026 - Change the scope of ISO 11243 ISO/TC 149/SC 1 agreed to change the scope of ISO 11243 as below; 1 Scope This document specifies safety and performance requirements for the design and testing of permanently attached luggage carriers, both non cycle specific luggage carriers intended for mounting and cycle specific luggage carriers mounted on complete cycles. It applies to luggage carriers intended to be positioned above and adjacent to the wheels of cycles. This document provides guidelines for instructions on the use and care of such luggage carriers. This document does not apply to removable luggage (for example, handlebar bags or baskets that are not permanently attached). Toy luggage carriers are not covered by this document. Reference: Call for comments on changing the title of ISO/CD 472-3
English title: Call for comments on changing the title of ISO/CD 472-3 “Plastics – Vocabulary – Part 3: Thermal joining of plastics”
Note: ISO/TC 61/SC 11/WG 14 “Plastic joining” is developing its project ISO/CD 472-3 “Plastics – Vocabulary – Part 3: Thermal joining of plastics”. At the last WG 14 meeting, WG 14 decided to recommend to SC 11 that the title of ISO/WD 472-3 be changed to “Plastics – Vocabulary – Part 3: Welding and thermal staking of plastics” for the following reasons a, b and c. (ISO/TC 61/SC 11/WG 14 N 12) Current title: “Plastics – Vocabulary – Part 3: Thermal joining of plastics” Proposed title: “Plastics – Vocabulary – Part 3: Welding and thermal staking of plastics” (Reasons) a. The document includes terms for solvent welding and solvent cement welding, which are carried out without the use of heat and are therefore not thermal joining processes. b. The term “thermal joining” was used rather than “welding” because the document includes terms on thermal staking, which is not a welding process. c. Adhesive bonding is excluded from this document. However, some adhesive bonding processes require heat and can therefore be classed as thermal joining processes. In other words, these reasons can be expressed as follows. (c) “thermal joining” includes hot melt adhesive bonding, which is outside the scope of WG 14. Therefore, “welding” is better than “thermal joining”. (a) “thermal joining” does not include “solvent welding” and “solvent cement welding”, whereas “welding” includes them. (b) On the other hand, “welding” does not include the terms on thermal staking. Therefore, “thermal staking” is included in the title. A CIB has been launched with the following question for members to consider: - Do you have any comments on this proposed title change? The CD consultation for this project is being conducted in parallel with this CIB.

English title: Unplasticized polyvinyl chloride (PVC) pipes and fittings — Determination and specification of density
Note: Reason for proposing withdrawal: The outcome of the SR ballot ISO 4439:1979 has been discussed with the SC 5 Chairperson. While the result of the ballot is Confirm, we believe that withdrawing the standard is in the best interest of the committee and its stakeholders. Arguments for withdrawing the standard: ISO 4439:1979 is not a test method (as should be under ISO/TC138/SC5). The test method is given in ISO 1183-1 and ISO 1183-2.ISO 4439:1979 specifies a density for PVC-U pipe or fitting between 1,35 g/cm3 and 1,46 g/cm3. Such specification belongs to the product standard. The following product standards (European standards included) either have a requirement for the density or made the choice not to include a requirement.EN 1401-1:2019+A1:2023 (Plastics piping systems for non-pressure underground drainage and sewerage - Unplasticized poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC-U) - Part 1: Specifications for pipes, fittings and the system) specifies a density between 1350 kg/m3 and 1600 kg/m3.ISO 4435:2003 (Plastics piping systems for non-pressure underground drainage and sewerage — Unplasticized poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC-U)) does not specify a requirement for the density, but refers to EN 1401-1 for PVC-U recyclate (which does contain a requirement).EN-ISO 1452-2:2009 and -3:2010 (Plastics piping systems for water supply and for buried and above-ground drainage and sewerage under pressure — Unplasticized poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC-U)) specify a density between 1350 kg/m3 and 1460 kg/m3EN-ISO 14593:2003 (Plastics piping systems for industrial applications — Acrylonitrile-butadiene-styrene (ABS), unplasticized poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC-U) and chlorinated poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC-C) — Specifications for components and the system — Metric series) specifies 1330 kg/m3 and 1460 kg/m3EN 13476 series (Plastics piping systems for non-pressure underground drains and sewers - Structured-wall piping systems of plasticized poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC-U), polypropylene (PP) and polyethylene (PE)) does not specify a requirement for the density, but it is a minimum agreed specification for PVC-U recyclate.EN 15346:2024 (Plastics - Recycled plastics - Characterization of poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC) recyclates) does not specify a requirement for the density, but mentions it as an optional characteristic.ISO 21138-1:2007 (Plastics piping systems for non-pressure underground drainage and sewerage — Structured-wall piping systems of unplasticized poly(vinyl chloride) (PVC-U), polypropylene (PP) and polyethylene (PE) — Part 1: Material specifications and performance criteria for pipes, fittings and system) states a general density of 1400 kg/m3No reference to “ISO 4439” can be found in other standards, using the ISO Online Browsing Plastform (OBP) Online Browsing Platform (OBP)The standard is not used in national regulations and can therefore be relatively safely withdrawn.
